ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read and understand various styles of econ articles. I also learned how to present the results of those papers.

Main thing I learned was presentation skills. Actually having to present non-trivial material was a valuable experience as it required fairly careful prep, as well as showing you the pitfalls and challenges of doing a good presentation.
Beyond those presentation skills also gained some knowledge about the different areas discussed in the course, including auctions, mechanism design, blockchain economics(!!), and some information economics.
Basics of mechanism design and auction theory, some stuff about blockchains, and information design. How to present mathematical results and write about them.

Learned all about auctions and voting and decision theory and all sorts of other cool topics I'd never been exposed to before. Probably the most useful skill, though, is just learning how to read a math paper, which outside of this course really isn't a skill you need to get through the math degree here (perhaps the math and econ degree is different, but I couldn't say).
More about the field of Econ Math research

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The presentation topics across weeks connected well and helped students develop an understanding of mechanism design and blockchain.
Weaknesses: The level of engagement was fairly low throughout the semester. It would be helpful for the professors to present some of the topics, or have smaller weekly assignments to allow students to work with the material regularly.
It would have benefited from a smaller class size and more lectures given by the instructors, given how knowledgeable they are

Content was interesting. Signups and logistics for presentations could have been better organized (mechanism design!) as is just felt like a scramble to choose a date as quickly as possible without having time to really consider what one wanted to present and some weeks ended up super over or under subscribed.

Strengths: Gave good practice presenting, and being able to watch others present made it even more valuable as you could see what they did which worked and didn't work and incorporate that into your presentations. We talked about interesting material and had really excellent guest speakers. Giving presentations required detailed preparation and actually understanding some of the material, which was good experience really digging into a piece of the literature. The final paper, similarly, allowed a pretty deep engagement with one area of interest.

Weaknesses: The presentations tried to cover way too much material. This meant that it was super difficult for other students to follow along beyond the initial setup, and this meant that the value of paying attention to the entire presentation was much lower than it could have been. This, as a side-effect, led to pretty low class engagement, with only a few people ever asking questions or making comments, and this made the course worse on the whole.

this course requires some major adjustments. Instead of having a general theme for the semester and letting students prepare presentations in some specific part in which they were interested, there was a rigid syllabus of papers for presenting which we had no say in. the general theme was "economics of the internet", which is very aligned with Professor Bergemann's work, but something I have no interest in. I believe the purpose of this course was to practice and get good at presenting. However, there were so many students in the class and everyone was required to present twice, so each person got roughly 15 minutes to present each time. In that time, we were expected to present a mathematical result, which is practically impossible to do well with the level of difficulty of the papers. What ended up happening was the presentations went way too fast through quite complex math, and no one paid any attention. Everyone's engagement was very low--you spent some hours in the week before your presentation making slides, and then did absolutely nothing and paid no attention for the rest of the semester. We also got no feedback on our presentations despite the fact that they were very hard to follow, some people seemed very unprepared, and/or didn't fully understand what they were presenting on.
Somehow the most positive part of the class was the final paper because I was able to actually write about something I am interested in, and got to apply some of the more general/fundamental results from the first couple of seminars to a specific environment.

Honestly there isn't much I would change about this course. It's a big switch up from the way literally every other math undergrad course here is taught, but not in a way that catches you off guard. The biggest weakness is bad student presenters, but that's not something that you can really work around in a course that's centered on student presentations. Dirk does intervene if anything is too difficult to understand (not in a scary "gotcha" kind of way though; more like throwing a lifeline to both the presenter and the class).

Strength Pretty chill course with some interesting topics, professors really cared about the topic and about their students
Weakness Did not enjoy writing the final paper

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The weekly presentation format in which each group consisted of 4-6 people was terrible from the perspective of learning. I could see the class working well with a smaller size however.
Probably is required for major, so not really applicable. If not required, or you have multiple options, then I would seriously look at which course covers material you find more interesting.

It is a requirement for the Econ-Math major and fulfils a requirement for the math major. A very small number of people in the class were taking it because they wanted to. I would not recommend this class if you don't have to take it, but you probably do.

If you're taking this, it's probably because you  have tothat's not to say it isn't a great course, though, only that nobody accidentally stumbles into math 481. You might have the option to take 480 instead, but being taught by Dirk Bergemann gives 481 the clear advantage. It's a fair bit for work for the two weeks in which you give presentations (and the final paper takes some time, but can be done early when you aren't busy), but other than that you just get to sit back and listen to lectures about interesting topics.
If its required for your major, yes
